markdownRemark.html:
Yes, it is possible for a team to get a touchback even if the ball doesn't touch the ground. To explain why, it is first necessary to define what exactly a touchback is. The NCAA college football rulebook gives the following two conditions for when a touchback should be declared:

ARTICLE 1. It is a touchback when:

a. The ball becomes dead out of bounds behind a goal line, except from an incomplete forward pass, or becomes dead in the possession of a player on, above or behind his own goal line and the attacking team is responsible for the ball being there (Rules 7-2-4-c) (A.R. 7-2-4-I, A.R. 8-6-1-I-III).

b. A kick becomes dead by rule behind the defending team’s goal line and the attacking team is responsible for the ball being there (Exception: Rule 8-4-2-b) (A.R. 6-3-4-III). 

From article 1a, if an attacking team causes the ball to go into the endzone (on, above, or behind the goal line), and a player gains possession there, it is a touchback. Say, for example, the attacking team punts the ball into the endzone and a defending player there successfully catches the ball and chooses not to run it out. That would be a touchback without the ball ever hitting the ground.

It is certainly possible for a touchback to occur when the ball does hit the ground. Article 1b covers such a scenario (for example, the attacking team punting the ball, which rolls into the endzone and comes to rest dead there). But touching the ground is not necessary for a touchback to occur.

Sources:

  1. College Football Rulebook
